verses.text: Ahab told Jezebel all that Elijah had done, and how he had killed all the prophets with the sword.
verses.comment: Stays close to Hebrew; ‘killed all the prophets’ refers to Baal’s prophets.

verses.text: Then Jezebel sent a messenger to Elijah, saying, 'May the gods do to me, and even more, if by this time tomorrow I do not make your life like the life of one of them.'
verses.comment: Uses 'May the gods do to me' as per Hebrew idiom for an oath.

verses.text: Then Elijah was afraid, and he arose and ran for his life. He came to Beersheba, which belongs to Judah, and left his servant there.
verses.comment: Some manuscripts have 'he saw'; most read 'he was afraid.'

verses.text: But he himself went a day's journey into the wilderness and sat down under a broom tree. He prayed that he might die, and said, 'It is enough now, LORD; take my life, for I am no better than my fathers.'
verses.comment: ‘Broom tree’ replaces ‘juniper’; ‘prayed that he might die’ for clarity.

verses.text: He lay down and slept under the broom tree. Suddenly, an angel touched him and said to him, 'Arise and eat.'
verses.comment: ‘Angel’ reflects Hebrew ‘messenger’; action is direct.

verses.text: He looked, and there beside his head was a cake baked on hot stones, and a jar of water. So he ate and drank, and lay down again.
verses.comment: ‘Cake baked on hot stones’ clarifies Hebrew cooking method.

verses.text: The angel of the LORD came again a second time and touched him, and said, 'Arise and eat, because the journey is too great for you.'
verses.comment: ‘The journey is too great for you’ is literal to Hebrew.

verses.text: So he arose, ate and drank, and went in the strength of that food forty days and forty nights to Horeb, the mountain of God.
verses.comment: ‘Horeb, the mountain of God’ is another name for Sinai.

verses.text: He came to a cave there and spent the night. Then the word of the LORD came to him, and said to him, 'What are you doing here, Elijah?'
verses.comment: Direct speech preserved; ‘a cave’ from Hebrew.

verses.text: He said, 'I have been very zealous for the LORD, the God of hosts. For the children of Israel have forsaken your covenant, torn down your altars, and killed your prophets with the sword. I alone am left, and they seek my life, to take it away.'
verses.comment: ‘God of hosts’ reflects ‘Yahweh Sabaoth’; ‘I alone am left’ as per Hebrew.

verses.text: And he said, 'Go out and stand on the mountain before the LORD.' And behold, the LORD passed by, and a great and strong wind tore into the mountains and broke the rocks in pieces before the LORD; but the LORD was not in the wind. And after the wind, an earthquake, but the LORD was not in the earthquake.
verses.comment: Keeps sequence and contrast of natural events as original.

verses.text: After the earthquake, a fire; but the LORD was not in the fire. And after the fire, a still small voice.
verses.comment: ‘Still small voice’ is traditional, literal rendering.

verses.text: When Elijah heard it, he wrapped his face in his cloak and went out and stood at the entrance of the cave. Then, a voice came to him and said, 'What are you doing here, Elijah?'
verses.comment: ‘Cloak’ is ‘mantle’ in some translations; ‘voice’ is literal.

verses.text: He said, 'I have been very zealous for the LORD, the God of hosts. For the children of Israel have forsaken your covenant, torn down your altars, and killed your prophets with the sword. I alone am left, and they seek my life, to take it away.'
verses.comment: Repeats verse 10 for emphasis in original Hebrew.

verses.text: And the LORD said to him, 'Go, return on your way to the wilderness of Damascus. When you arrive, anoint Hazael to be king over Aram.'
verses.comment: ‘Aram’ is Syria; ‘anoint’ as in setting apart by oil.

verses.text: 'Also anoint Jehu, son of Nimshi, to be king over Israel; and anoint Elisha, son of Shaphat of Abel-meholah, to be prophet in your place.'
verses.comment: ‘Abel-meholah’ left as the Hebrew place name.

verses.text: 'It will happen that whoever escapes the sword of Hazael, Jehu will kill; and whoever escapes the sword of Jehu, Elisha will kill.'
verses.comment: ‘Whoever escapes…’ as per Hebrew causal structure.

verses.text: 'Yet I have preserved seven thousand in Israel, all whose knees have not bowed to Baal, and all whose mouths have not kissed him.'
verses.comment: ‘Preserved’ instead of ‘left’, per literal Hebrew verb.

verses.text: So Elijah departed and found Elisha son of Shaphat, who was plowing with twelve pairs of oxen before him, and he was with the twelfth. Elijah passed by him and threw his cloak over him.
verses.comment: ‘Cloak’ for ‘mantle’; sets up prophetic succession.

verses.text: Elisha left the oxen, ran after Elijah, and said, 'Let me kiss my father and my mother, then I will follow you.' Elijah said to him, 'Go back again, for what have I done to you?'
verses.comment: ‘Go back again, for what have I done to you?’ is a common Hebrew expression.

verses.text: So he returned from him, took the pair of oxen and slaughtered them. He boiled their flesh with the yoke's wood and gave it to the people, and they ate. Then he got up and followed Elijah, and ministered to him.
verses.comment: ‘Ministered to him’ means serving as an apprentice prophet.
